data.title: Louise Dupin's Work on Women: Selections
data.text:
Cite

Select Format

Abstract

Part II engages in feminist historiography. Claiming that women are absent from the historical record only because (male) historians have written them out of it, this section transforms the old genre of the Querelle des femmes through its global aspirations. Testimony from travel narratives provides examples of female rulers up to the modern colonial era as well as ethnographic evidence that disproves the universality of women’s inequality to men. Salic law, which excluded women from the throne of France, is criticized as a fabrication. The exclusion of women from roles of ecclesiastical authority is discredited as an innovation through evidence gleaned in canon law, while compilations of legal cases are used to demonstrate the resistance of French female monastic orders to their disenfranchisement and enclosure following the Council of Trent.
